items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: Scarface is one of those special movies, like "The Godfather," that is willing to take a flawed, evil man and allow him to be human.
Perfomances are excellent, and despite its moralistic conclusion, the film has since become de rigueur viewing for crack barons, who know a good shoot-em-up when they see one.

items.author: TV Guide Magazine
items.content: A beautiful, at times poetic exercise in excess from Brian De Palma.

items.author: Vincent Canby
items.content: Scarface is the most stylish and provocative - and maybe the most vicious - serious film about the American underworld since Francis Ford Coppola's "Godfather."

items.author: Richard Corliss
items.content: It is a serious, often hilarious peek under the rock where nightmares strut in $800 suits and Armageddon lies around the next twist of treason.
Scarface is a grandiose modern morality play, excessive, broad and operatic at times.

items.author: Jay Scott
items.content: Scarface is a B- movie with singularly silly psychological pretensions: its neo-primitivism is to the complex moral cosmos of Francis Coppola's "Godfather" saga as Disney is to Dickens. [09 Dec 1983]

items.author: Jay Carr
items.content: It plays like a crude "Godfather" parody, the sort that might amuse as a 10-minute sketch on "Saturday Night Live," but curdles and collapses as a 143-minute film. [09 Dec 1983]

items.author: Dave Kehr
items.content: Brian De Palma dedicates this 1983 feature to Howard Hawks and Ben Hecht, authors of the 1932 original, though I doubt they would find much honor in his gory inflation of their crisp, 90-minute comic nightmare into a klumbering, self-important, arrhythmic downer of nearly three hours.
